_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Corning Wastewater Treatment Facility accidental release prevention program involves a
unified approach that integrates technologies, policy, and management practices. It is in compliance
with EPA Risk Management Program requirements including Cal OES CalARP requirements.
The responsibility of the RMP has been assigned to the WWTP operator who will review the
program at least on an annual basis.
Process Safety Information. The Corning WWTP has developed and maintains written safety
information about the chlorination and de-chlorination process and the technology of process
equipment used. The operation of this facility adheres to the guidelines of the Chlorine Institute and
to the OSHA regulations regarding Process Safety Management. Process Safety Information is
readily available to all personnel and is updated when changes are made.
Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)The original PHA review was conducted in June 2009 appropriate to the
complexity of the chlorination process that identified, evaluated, and controlled potential hazards
using the What-If Checklist and a Hazard Review Checklists processes. These processes
include the analysis of hazards due to equipment malfunction and human error. It describes steps
used to detect and monitor releases. This PHA will be updated every three years and the Corning WWTP will conduct reviews whenever major changes occur to the process.
Operating Procedures. The WWTP plant operator has prepared written standard operating
procedures specific to their operations that provide clear instructions for the safe operational
activities associated with the process. These procedures are included in the facility operations
manual and the Process Safety Management manual. The manual includes procedures for
operation of all phases of the processes, and normal and emergency shutdown of the process.
These procedures will be reviewed and updated if necessary on an annual basis. All WWTP
operators have taken a di

rect role in the development of the operating procedures.
Employee Training: - All existing and newly assigned employees and/or contractors are trained and
tested competent in all operation procedures. Training documentation is maintained on all
applicable employees, refresher training is provided quarterly. The training documentation will be
reviewed at least annual to ensure trainings have been completed.
Mechanical Integrity. The WWTP has a preventive maintenance program that insures the mechanical integrity of its chlorination / de-chlorination processing equipment,
which includes periodic inspection, testing and an annual overhaul of critical processing equipment.
Maintenance procedures are written for each step of the maintenance process and assigned to
appropriate personnel.
Management of Change (MOC) The WWTP has implemented written MOC procedures to
manage changes (except changes in-kind) to process chemical technology, equipment and
procedures. Employees affected by a change in a process are informed of and trained in the
change prior to start up of the process or affected part of the process. Safety information and
operation procedures are updated accordingly.
Pre-Startup Review. Written standard operational procedures have been developed to allow
operators to perform a pre-startup safety review for new and modified chlorination equipment, or
where modification to the process is significant enough to require a change in the process safety
information.
Compliance Audits. A compliance audit was performed in June 2009 and will be performed
every three years to verify that the procedures and practices are adequate and are
being followed. The WWTP operators and additional qualified resources will perform the audit. A
report will be developed to summarize the review and findings. Any recommended actions will be
presented to City of Corning for corrective actions. The two most recent audits will be kept.
Incident Investigation. The Corning

WWTP operators will investigate any incident involving the
chemical system which could result or does result in a release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas. The
investigation will be conducted within 48 hours of the incident. All key factors will be addressed and
recommendations for correction will result. Affected personnel will review the findings of the
investigation. The report will be kept for 5 years.
Employee Participation The managers and operators of the Corning WWTP participated in the
process hazard analysis conducted in May 2009. The PHA will be made available to all affected
employees and is stored in the RMP binder.
Hot Work Permit A hot work permit process has been developed and implemented for hot work
operations conducted on or near the chlorination and de-chlorination process. The permit
documents the fire and accident prevention requirements and is implemented prior to beginning any
hot work operations. The permit is kept at the work site until the completion of any hot work. All
completed hot work permits will be retained for at least one year following completion of work.
Contractors working on or near the water treatment plant are required to comply with
the regulatory provisions of the Risk Management Program and Cal ARP standards. A form has been
developed to address the following: contractor safety program; informing contractor employees of
the hazards on the site; review of the emergency evacuation plans; record contractor meetings of
the plans; and require contractors to train their employees on the hazards of the process. Copies of
the forms and documentation are retained in the RMP binder.
Injury and Illness Prevention Program. The Corning WWTP has an active IIPP meeting
the requirements of Cal/OSHA Section 3203 that addresses the following;

Incident and Accident investigation process for all safety related incidents at the facility
Emergency Response Program. The Corning WWTP has established a working relationsh

ip with
the City of Corning Fire Department. Regular meetings are conducted to ensure there is effective
interaction and communication with local and state response agencies. The Tehama County
Environmental Management Department, as part of their business plan program, is notified
immediately if there is a hazardous material release. The City of Corning Fire Department will be the
incident commander in the case of a chlorine release and will coordinate evacuation procedures in a
worst-case scenario.
The emergency response will depend on the immediate situation as determined by the incident
commander. A list of emergency response scenarios is being developed with the fire department
during the periodic meetings. The major elements of the emergency response plan are:
Upon activation of alarm, notification of all non-essential personnel who are not involved in the
emergency response process (visitors, contractors, employees)
Evacuate the facility to a safe location based upon the direction of the air movement
Notify City of Corning Fire Department, restrict entry to the facility, Establish the Incident Command Structure with Corning Fire Department. The written emergency response plan is provided in the RMP manual.
